title: 109_s2475
content: The Act titled "Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community Act of 2006" establishes a commission. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community consists of 23 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, minority leader of the House, majority leader of the Senate, and minority leader of the Senate. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community consists of 23 members appointed by various officials, including nonvoting members appointed by key leaders in the House and Senate. Members must have a commitment to American Latino life, art, history, or culture, along with expertise in museum administration. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community requires members with expertise in museum administration, fundraising for nonprofit institutions, teaching Latino culture, studying Smithsonian's representation of Latino art, or experience in public service. The curr_chunk is about the establishment of museums dedicated to studying and promoting the role of ethnic, racial, or cultural groups in American history. The curr_chunk focuses on outlining the functions of the commission established to promote the role of ethnic, racial, or cultural groups in American history. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress with recommendations for establishing and maintaining a National Museum of the American Latino Community in Washington, DC. They will also develop fundraising plans and examine issues related to the Museum in consultation with the Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress on the availability, cost, impact, possible locations, governance, and organizational structure of the National Museum of the American Latino Community in Washington, DC. The Commission will submit a report to Congress on the governance and organizational structure of the National Museum of the American Latino Community, as well as how to engage the community in its development and design. Legislation will be proposed to carry out the recommendations in the report. The Commission will convene a national conference on the Museum, comprised of individuals dedicated to American Latino life, art, history, and culture, within 9 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS. The Secretary of the Interior provides administrative services, facilities, and funds for the Commission's functions. Commission members not employed by the government receive compensation and travel expenses as determined by the Secretary of the Interior. The Commission must submit final reports, plans, and recommendations within 18 months of the Act's enactment and terminate within 30 days of submission. $2.1 million is authorized for fiscal year 2007 and $1.1 million for fiscal year 2008 for Commission activities.
